children.name: to destroy an area or place
destroy
children.definition: /dɪˈstrɔɪ/  to damage something sobadlythat itcannotberepaired:
examples: phá hủy
▪ The earthquake destroyed much of the city.
▪ In Brazil the rainforests are gradually being destroyed.
▪ The factory was almost completely destroyed by fire.

children.name: devastate
children.definition: /ˈdevəsteɪt/  to cause so much damage over alargearea that most of the buildings, trees, and crops there are destroyed:
examples: tàn phá, phá hủy
▪ A huge explosion devastated the downtown area last night.
▪ The country has been devastated by floods.
▪ Years of war have devastated this island nation.

children.name: wreck
children.definition: /rek/  todeliberatelydamage abuildingorroomverybadly:
examples: phá phách
▪ He came home drunk again, threatening to wreck the apartment.
▪ Bulldozers were brought in to wreck the tents and shacks that protesters had put up.

children.name: demolish
children.definition: /dɪˈmɒlɪʃǁdɪˈmɑː-/  to destroy abuildingusingspecialequipment, because it isoldornot safe:
examples: làm sụp đổ, phá hủy
▪ Eventually, in 1997, the apartment block was demolished.
▪ When they demolished the church, a cave was discovered beneath it.

children.name: knock down
children.definition: alsopull downBritish /ˌnɒk ˈdaʊnǁˌnɑːk-, ˌpʊl ˈdaʊn/  todeliberatelydestroy abuildingorwallbecause it isnotnowneeded,notsafeetc: :
examples: làm sụp đổ , phá hủy
knock/pull down something
▪ If you knocked down this wall, the living room would be a lot bigger.
▪ She was brought up in a tatty little house that has since been pulled down.
knock/pull something down
▪ They’ll have to knock down these houses when they build the new road.

children.name: be flattened
children.definition: /biː ˈflætnd/  if an area such as a town or forest is flattened all the buildings or trees there are destroyed by bombs, storms etc:
examples: bị san phẳng, bị san bằng
▪ It will cost $400 million to rebuild the houses that were flattened in the fighting.
be flattened by
bị san bằng bởi
▪ Thousands of miles of woodland were flattened by storms last month.

children.name: obliterate
children.definition: /əˈblɪtəreɪt/  to destroy a place so completely that nothing remains, and it is difficult to see or imagine what was once there:
examples: phá sạch, xóa sạch
▪ Entire sections of the city were obliterated by the repeated bombing.
▪ Frequent flooding eventually obliterated all traces of the community that used to live there.

children.name: be ravaged by
children.definition: /biː ˈrævɪdʒd baɪ/  if a place or an area is ravaged by war, fire etc, it is very badly damaged and a lot of it is destroyed - used especially in newspapers and news reports:
examples: bị tàn phá bởi
▪ The country has been ravaged by civil war for the last 10 years.
▪ North Africa and the Middle East are regularly ravaged by plagues of locusts.

children.name: reduce st to rubble
children.definition: reduce something to rubble/ashesetc/rɪˌdjuːs something tə ˈrʌbəlǁrɪˌduːs-/  to completely destroy a building:
examples: phá hủy thành tro bụi
▪ Their new two-storey house had been reduced to ashes in the fire.
▪ We won’t stand by while developers reduce the historic remains of the city to rubble.

children.name: trash
children.definition: /træʃ/  informal to deliberately destroy a lot of the things in a room, house, etc:
examples: phá tung
▪ Someone had broken in and trashed her apartment.
▪ Band members have been accused of trashing their hotel rooms.

children.name: wreck
children.definition: /rek/  to damage a car, boat etc very badly in anaccidentso that it cannot be used again:
examples: phá hoại, làm hỏng
▪ They had stolen a car and wrecked it on the freeway.
▪ Glen drove right into a tree and wrecked his car.
wrecked[adjective]
bị hỏng
▪ Wrecked vehicles lay abandoned at the roadside.

children.name: write off
children.definition: /ˌraɪt ˈɒf/  British /totalAmerican /ˈtəʊtl/  to damage a vehicle, especially a car, so badly in anaccidentthat it cannot be repaired or used again:
examples: làm tan tành
▪ I totaled my car in a blizzard once, and I won’t drive in the snow anymore.
write off something/write something off
phá tan thứ gì / xóa sổ thứ gì
▪ She wrote her mother’s car off the first time she drove it.

children.name: a place or thing that is destroyed
wreckage
children.definition: /ˈrekɪdʒ/  the broken parts of a car, plane etc that has crashed:
examples: mảnh vỡ, vật đổ nát
▪ Wreckage from the plane was scattered over a large area.
▪ Investigators are looking through pieces of the wreckage for any clues about the crash.

children.name: ruins
children.definition: /ˈruːɪnz, ˈruːənz/  the parts of abuildingortownthat remain after it has been destroyed:
examples: tàn tích
▪ The tour will visit ancient monasteries and Roman ruins in Merida.
ruins of
▪ Gunfire still echoed through the ruins of the city.

children.name: wreck
children.definition: /rek/  ashipthat has been sunk, or acarthat has been very badly damaged in a crash:
examples: xác tàu , xe
▪ Divers went down to search the wreck.
▪ The car was a complete wreck, but the driver escaped with minor injuries.

children.name: write-off
children.definition: /ˈraɪt ɒf/  British acarthat has been so badly damaged that it cannot be used again:
examples: đồ bỏ đi
▪ The car was a complete write-off - I was lucky I wasn’t killed.

children.name: destructive
children.definition: /dɪˈstrʌktɪv/  likely to destroy something or cause serious damage to it:
examples: tàn phá, hủy diệt
▪ The border war has been wasteful and destructive.
▪ The destructive side-effects of pesticides are now well known.
▪ Alcoholics often tend to have stormy and destructive relationships.

children.name: devastating
children.definition: /ˈdevəsteɪtɪŋ/  causing very serious damage to all the buildings, trees, crops etc in anarea, so that they are almost completely destroyed:
examples: tàn phá, hủy diệt
▪ The palace was rebuilt in 1832 after a devastating fire.
have a devastating effect
▪ The oil spill had a devastating effect on sea birds and other wildlife.

children.name: destruction
children.definition: /dɪˈstrʌkʃən/  when something is destroyed:
examples: sự phá hủy
▪ The war caused widespread death and destruction.
destruction of
sự phá hủy
▪ The destruction of forests for timber, fuel, and charcoal increased during the 18th century.

children.name: demolition
children.definition: /ˌdeməˈlɪʃən/  the deliberate destruction of abuilding, because it is inbadcondition or in order to build anewone:
examples: sự phá hủy
▪ The old factory will be knocked down by demolition experts.
demolition of
sự phá hủy
▪ Building the new freeway is going to mean the demolition of an entire housing complex.

children.name: devastation
children.definition: /ˌdevəˈsteɪʃən/  the result of an area being completely and violently destroyed:
examples: sự tàn phá, sự phá hủy
▪ Few buildings in the city had escaped devastation.
utter devastationcomplete devastation
▪ The scene after the explosion was one of utter devastation.
sự phá hủy hoàn toàn

children.name: be/lie in ruins
children.definition: /biː, laɪ ɪn ˈruːnz/  if a town or building is in ruins or lies in ruins, it has been completely destroyed:
examples: trở thành phế tích
▪ After the war entire neighborhoods lay in ruins.
leave something in ruins
khiến cái gì trở thành tàn tích
▪ Four days and nights of continuous bombing had left the city in ruins.

children.name: demolish
children.definition: /dɪˈmɒlɪʃǁdɪˈmɑː-/  to destroy a building using special equipment, because it is old or not safe:
examples: phá hủy, đánh đổ
▪ Eventually, in 1997, the apartment block was demolished.
▪ When they demolished the church, a cave was discovered beneath it.

children.name: knock down
children.definition: alsopull downBritish /ˌnɒk ˈdaʊnǁˌnɑːk-, ˌpʊl ˈdaʊn/  to deliberately destroy a building or wall because it is not now needed, not safe etc:
examples: phá sập, đánh đổ
knock/pull down something
phá sập thứ gì đó
▪ If you knocked down this wall, the living room would be a lot bigger.
▪ She was brought up in a tatty little house that has since been pulled down.
knock/pull something down
phá sập thứ gì đó
▪ They’ll have to knock down these houses when they build the new road.

children.name: tear down
children.definition: /ˌteəʳ ˈdaʊn/  to deliberately destroy a building or other structure, especially in order to put something else in its place - use this especially when you do not approve of this action:
examples: phá sập, đánh đổ
tear down something
phá sập thứ gì đó
▪ We need laws to keep people from tearing down these beautiful old buildings.
tear something down
phá sập thứ gì đó
▪ I’ll be really upset if they tear the old theater down.

children.name: to destroy sb’s relationships, hopes, happiness etc
destroy
children.definition: /dɪˈstrɔɪ/  to destroy someone’s relationships, hopes, happiness etc:
examples: phá hủy
▪ Even close relationships can be destroyed by alcoholism.
▪ Few things destroy trust more than telling a friend’s secrets.
▪ Chandler worried that the scandal would destroy his chances for a respectable career.

children.name: wreck
children.definition: /rek/  to completely destroy someone’s relationships, hopes, chances etc, especially by doing or saying something without thinking of the likely results:
examples: phá hủy
▪ Ron’s affair wrecked our marriage.
▪ His confrontational speech has wrecked any chances of a peace settlement.

children.name: break sb’s spirit
children.definition: break somebody’s spirit/resolve/will etc/ˌbreɪk somebodyˈs ˈspɪrt/  to destroy someone’s determination although they have tried hard to keep it:
examples: phá vỡ, đập tan
▪ Years in prison did not break Mr Mandela’s spirit.
▪ Her captors used violence and psychological torture to try to break her will.

children.name: ruin
children.definition: /ˈruːɪn, ˈruːən/  to completely spoil or destroy someone’s chances, hopes, relationship etc:
examples: phá hủy, làm hỏng
▪ Phelps’s mistake has ruined her chances of winning the championship.
▪ Patty’s ex-boyfriend is ruining our relationship.

children.name: vandalize
children.definition: also vandalise British /ˈvændəl-aɪz/  to deliberately damagebuildings,vehicles, orpublicproperty:
examples: phá hoại có chủ ý
▪ All the public telephones in the area had been vandalized.
Tất cả các điện thoại công cộng ở khu vực này đã bị cố ý phá hoại
▪ No-one is really sure why people vandalize their own neighbourhoods.
Không ai thực sự chắc chắn được vì sao con người lại cố ý phá hoại nơi sống của chính họ
vandal[countable noun] someone who vandalizes things::
kẻ phá hoại
▪ Vandals broke into the school and wrecked two classrooms.
Kẻ phá hoại đã phá ngôi trường và làm hỏng hai lớp học
vandalism[uncountable noun] the criminal activity of vandalizing things:
▪ In recent years, there has been an increase in vandalism in inner-city areas.

children.name: smash up
children.definition: /ˌsmæʃ ˈʌp/  British todeliberatelydamage aroomorbuildingby breaking windows, furniture etc:
examples: phá hoại, đập phá
smash something up
đập phá cái gì
▪ They didn’t only rob the house, they smashed it up too.
Chúng không chỉ ăn cắp, chúng còn đập phá căn nhà nữa
smash up something
đập phá cái gì
▪ About 400 rioters had seized control and were smashing up the jail.
Khoảng chừng 400 tên phá rối đã nắm quyền và đập phá nhà tù
smash the place up
đập phá nơi này
▪ Some of the men got drunk and smashed the place up.
Vài tên đàn ông đã say xỉn và đập phá nơi này

children.name: sabotage
children.definition: /ˈsæbətɑːʒ/  to secretly damagemachinesorequipmentso that they cannot be used, especially in order toharm an enemy:
examples: phá hủy, phá hoại, làm hư hại
▪ The railway line had been sabotaged by enemy commandos.
Đường ray xe lửa đã bị phá hủy bởi đặc công của địch
▪ Security lighting was sabotaged before the theft took place.
Đèn an ninh đã bị phá hủy trước khi tên trộm lẻn vào
sabotage[uncountable noun] when people secretly damage machines or equipment:
sự phá hoại, sự phá hỏi
▪ Armed soldiers patrol the airbase to guard against sabotage.
Các người lính vũ trang tuần tra căn cứ không quân để đề phòng sự phá hoại
